Articles.Content:
I plan to be a rocket designer when I "grow up" so I've started to play a lot of RSS and RO recently to help me acclimate to the rigors of real-world rocket design. (Yes, I know it's not a perfect simulation of real life- but it's the closest consumer-grade simulation you're going to get.)

Thing is, I'm HORIFFICALLY bad at it. Part of this is due to the limitations of the computer that I'm running it on- it's a Mac, which has an even lower memory limit than Windows, so "critical existence failures" are quite common. Another part of is that I JUST started playing with RemoteTech, so it's quite common for me to lose line-of-sight communications.... oh.... just as I need to perform final circularization.

Anyways, here's the list of AstroLift flights prior to me making this thread:

AL-01: Successful SSTO test, deploying a 1.17 ton communications satellite into a 200x120 orbit with high inclination. Took about 10 test flights until it worked. (Would be less if the RS-25 was restartable, which it should be- it's an excellent engine for SSTOs- had to include 3 extra restartable hydrolox engines to offset this fact. PLEASE make TEATEB MFT compatible, NathanKell...) Sadly, SSTO was not recoverable due to me not including enough fuel, or parachutes, or indeed any recovery equipment of any kind.

AL-02: Test 1 of the "Magnum Dragon" lifter: a TSTO with 4 Falcon 1Ds on the first stage, 4 RD-120s on the second. 5 ton payload. Suffered a loss of communication over the Atlantic Ocean, leading to its untimely destruction.

AL-03: Test 2 of the "Magnum Dragon" lifter. Test proceeded perfectly until premature staging of the payload while attempting to perform fairing sep.

AL-04: Test 3 of the "Magnum Dragon" lifter. Test suffered critical existence failure.

More to come soon.

Edited September 4, 2015 by Kagame

Good news! I think I'm finally getting the hang of this whole "getting into orbit in RSS and RO" thing!

Flight AL-005 "Taper I" smallsat launcher (3 tons to LEO):

This one relied on a rather toxic first stage, so I wouldn't reccomend using it IRL.

Long-range commsat deployed! Now I only need to put up about twenty more of these things...

Flight AL-006: "Taper II" medium lifter (6 tons to LEO with almost enough dV left over to put it into GTO, putting LEO mass ~7-8t)

Liftoff! This one uses a traditional kerolox first stage of 4 clustered RS-27As.

Circularization on a pair of RL-60s- a dood reccomended them to me on IRC, and I must say, they work mag-ni-fi-cent-ly.

This was the heaviest satellite I could possibly design- every concievable bit of scientific/spying equipment. Just so happens it was deployed into an orbit that passes over a good bit of Pakistan and Russia... NRO was satisfied.

On the plus side, we got to keep al the biome and altimetry data! Woot!

Next: the flight of the "Gamera" medium-heavy lifter, capable of taking 23t to LEO- in this case, a station core by one R. Bigelow. Funny how this one doesn't inflate...
